attributes.name: Uses large muscles to move & balance own body
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may crawl, pull up, and/or walk. An older child may walk on a balance beam, jump over a tree stump, or pull a wagon.

progressionPoints.description: Demonstrates strength & control of head, arms, legs, & trunk
Explores new body positions & movements, such as rolling, sitting, & crawling
Moves with increased coordination, with or without adult support
Demonstrates control in changing body position & movements such as sitting to standing, stooping, running
Balances with increasing coordination
Uses non-locomotor skills with increased control and coordination
Performs activities that require coordination of several large muscle movements
Demonstrates strength & stamina in participation of physical activities
Increases muscle strength and gains greater control over large and fine motor development
Travels within a large group, without bumping into others or falling, while using locomotor skills

attributes.name: Uses large muscles to explore & interact with the environment
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may reach for objects in the environment. An older child may climb an outdoor play structure.

progressionPoints.description: Uses body position & posture to explore & interact with environment
Uses balance & movement to explore & interact with environment
Uses large motor skills such as running, climbing, throwing, to explore environment
Experiments with body movement through simple game play and/or dancing to music
Develops an increasing awareness of body & space; allowing for gradually increasing coordinated movement
Moves body in relation to objects to effectively perform a task
Understands directional movement (positioning oneself on top, below, to the side of something or someone)
Demonstrates running and can easily change directions. Can climb elevated structures with minimal adult support.
Develops and refines throwing, catching and kicking skills
Engages in complex movements (skipping, dribbling a ball)

attributes.name: Uses hands & fingers to explore & interact with the environment
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may feed and/or dress themselves. An older child may manipulate small toys or objects, or use a pencil to write a story.

progressionPoints.description: Uses hands to explore the properties of materials, such as feeling or shaking objects
Uses eye-hand coordination to complete simple tasks
Uses both hands in coordinated ways to engage in play, routines, & self-care
Uses simple tools to engage in play, routines, & self-care
Uses eye-hand coordination to perform more complex tasks such as cutting or drawing simple shapes
Uses pincer grasp with thumb & fingers to manipulate objects
Uses more complex tools to engage in play
Demonstrates precision in hand-eye coordinated tasks
Coordinates the use of both hands
Performs actions involving opposing hand movements (buttoning clothing, starting and zipping up a zipper)
Uses tools for writing, drawing, cutting

attributes.name: Uses senses to explore & interact with the environment
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may dance to music. An older child may engage in tasting different types of apples or observing changes in nature.

progressionPoints.description: Visually Tracks or reaches for an object
Explores objects using hands and mouth
Uses senses to develop a basic understanding of objects and the environment
Uses information derived from senses to understand and adjust how to interact with objects and the environment
Uses senses to understand their environment and then can apply simple reasoning to ask questions and learn more about what they just experienced

attributes.name: Expresses, understands, & regulates emotions
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may smile when happy or frown when upset. An older child may share that they need space when upset about an event.

progressionPoints.description: Expresses a variety of emotions through sounds, gestures, facial expressions, & movement
Is comforted by a familiar adult
Responds to others' emotional expressions, with a shared emotional reaction
Seeks comfort when needed from familiar adults or engages in self-comforting behaviors
Expresses a broad range of emotions & begins to manage those emotions with support
Uses words to describe feelings or emotions that reflect an understanding or awareness of the emotions of others
Begins to express and notice subtle and/or complex emotions in self & others
Manages the expression of feelings with minimal guidance
Values fairness and can consider another's perspective
Can show self-control over emotional reactions, most of the time
Identifies and describes the experience of different feelings (such as elation, joy, grief, and rage) and how feelings affect daily functioning

attributes.name: Develops positive relationships with adults
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may get excited when a familiar teacher walks into the room. An older child may ask a teacher to play a favorite game with them.

progressionPoints.description: Communicates with familiar adults by using a variety of behaviors such as crying, smiling, pointing, & reaching
Looks to or seeks help from familiar adults
Uses familiar adults for reassurance when engaging with new adults
Shows affection & preference for familiar adults
Displays enjoyment in interactions with trusted adults
Initiates interaction with trusted adults
Asks and answers questions about what an adult says in order to gather additional information or clarify something that is not understood

attributes.name: Develops positive relationships with other children
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may cooperatively share space or materials with another child. An older child may play a back and forth game with another child.

progressionPoints.description: Displays interest in, & recognition of, other children
Participates in simple imitation games
Participates in simple back-and-forth interactions with another child
Seeks out other children for social interaction & shows preference for a certain child or children
Joins in play with other children by taking turns or doing joint activities
Engages in joint play using coordinated goals, planning, roles, and rules
Engages in reflection and conversation about past play experiences
Begins to resolve social conflict & negotiate with peers
Be able to make friends
Respects the rights of others
Has sense of empathy and interest in fairness
Uses thinking skills and communication to resolve conflict

attributes.name: Develops a sense of identity & belonging
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may be intrigued with exploring their hands and feet. An older child may create a self-portrait.

progressionPoints.description: Begins to learn about self through exploration of hands, feet, body, movement, & their capacities
Shows awareness of own thoughts, feelings, & preferences
Shows confidence in increasing abilities
Identifies physical similarities & differences between self & others & makes comparisons
Recognizes own name
Identifies self as a member of a family
Identifies the diversity in human characteristics & how people are similar and different
Uses labels to describe their own physical characteristics
Feels a sense of pride, but not superiority about racial and cultural identity
Learns to recognize injustice and takes action against inequitable behaviors
Can begin to identify stereotypes and differences within group categories

attributes.name: Manages actions & behaviors
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may use self-soothing behaviors. An older child may ask for help with a difficult task.

progressionPoints.description: Shows preference for familiar adults when in distress
Asks for help or assistance when encountering difficult tasks or situations
Uses basic strategies for dealing with common conflicts, such as sharing, taking turns, & compromising
Expresses feelings, needs, and opinions in conflict situations; utilizing adult support as needed.
Manages the expression of feelings, thoughts, impulses, & behaviors with minimal guidance from adults
Demonstrates ability to delay gratification.
Follows adult guidelines & expectations for appropriate behavior
Understands the importance of making appropriate choices and that they are based on expectations in the classroom/school
Regulates emotions with minimal adult support, most of the time

attributes.name: Understands & follows rules, routine
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A younger child may wash hands before a meal. An older child may wear a helmet for bike riding.

progressionPoints.description: Participates in daily routines as/when initiated by adult
Learns and follows some simple rules and routines with adult support
Aware of, participates in, and follows everyday routines
Responds to signals when transitioning from one activity to another
Identifies and follows safety rules
Understands expectations of fire safety, bus safety, and seatbelt use
Give examples that show the meaning of the following concepts: authority, fairness, justice and responsibility
Respects and cares for the classroom environment

attributes.name: Develops increasing care for self, others, & environment
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A child may help to put materials away when making a transition.

progressionPoints.description: Shows interest in, and imitates some personal-care tasks
Repeats care moments during play
Participates in personal-care tasks with support
Cleans up & puts materials away appropriately with adult support
Completes personal care tasks with increasing independence
Handles & takes care of classroom materials by using them in appropriate ways
Responds in caring ways to others
Expresses concern and support for the needs of others
Independently cleans up & puts materials away appropriately
Describes positive ways to show care, consideration, and concern for others
Maintains a clean working space, with minimal reminders from an adult

attributes.name: Listens to, understands, & responds to communication from others
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may make sounds when interacting with an adult or another child. An older child may engage in conversational turn-taking.

progressionPoints.description: Participates in reciprocal interactions by exchanging facial expressions & language sounds
Shows understanding of some words & phrases by responding to simple questions and/or following one step directions
Understands and responds (verbally & non-verbally) to increasingly longer sentences, simple questions, & simple stories
Shows acknowledgement of complex comments or questions
Is able to attend to longer, multi-turn conversations and respond appropriately
Listens to others and takes turns speaking about topics and texts under discussion
Asks and answers questions about what a speaker says.  Can gather and clarify information in order to strengthen comprehension
Listens to peers and adults  in order to resolve conflict and formulate appropriate questions

attributes.name: Uses verbal & non-verbal communication to express needs, wants, & ideas
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may use the sign for "more" during a mealtime. An older child may stand up and share an experience with other children in a large group meeting.

progressionPoints.description: Uses varying ways of communicating interests or needs to others, such as sounds or signs
Combines words or signs from one or more languages into phrases to communicate needs, wants, or ideas.
Uses simple sentences and/or signs to communicate needs wants, or ideas.
Uses language, spoken or sign, for a variety of purposes; providing sufficient details to get needs met and/or to provide clarification
Speaks audibly & expresses thoughts, feelings, & ideas clearly
Uses conventions of standard English
Talks about the characters and what happened in a story or poem, with help from adults
Tells what they think (their opinion) or how they feel about something
Claps or moves in ways that match the rhythm of a poem or song

attributes.name: Understands & uses a growing vocabulary
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may point to a picture of a cat when an adult uses that word. An older child may begin to understand categories of words such as cat, dog, bird, fish are all animals.

progressionPoints.description: Looks at familiar people or objects when they are named
Uses signs or verbalizations for familiar people or objects.
Responds appropriately to the meaning of words or signs used by adults
Imitates new words & uses an increasing number of words in communication
Comprehends an increasing number of words or signs; particularly those used in daily activities & asks questions about word meanings
Understands most positional words
Demonstrates an understanding of word categories, shared characteristics of words & word meanings, & the ability to distinguish between similar words
Use words and phrases like left, far, in front of, and between to explain where people, animals, and things are
Use words and phrases like before, afternoon, next week, and long ago to explain when events happened or will happen
Use knowledge of English grammar and vocabulary in both speech and writing

attributes.name: Understands & uses social & conversational rules
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may babble back to an adult as they are being spoken to. An older child may ask follow up questions after having read a story.

progressionPoints.description: Participates in serve and return conversations with non-verbal facial expressions, sounds, & gestures
Asks simple questions using gestures, signs, and/or words with variation in pitch and intonation
Seeks information & meaning by asking questions in a variety of ways
Participates in simple conversations; maintained by back-and-forth exchanges of ideas or information
Maintains multi-turn conversations with adults, children, & groups by responding in sophisticated ways, such as asking related questions or expressing agreement
Participates in conversations appropriately based on group size and expectations
Uses words to resolve conflicts, solve problems, or negotiate with peers
Asks original and complex questions
Talks in a group, shares information, and express feelings

attributes.name: Demonstrates phonological awareness
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may experiment with repeating sounds like "bababa". An older child may be able to identify the first letter of a word based on the sound they hear... "Flower starts with the letter... F!"

progressionPoints.description: Vocalizes sounds & experiments with common first sounds such as "mama" or "baba".
Repeats particularly pleasing sounds
Recognizes familiar sounds
Demonstrates rhyme recognition
Produces beginning sounds in spoken words when prompted & with support, if needed
Identifies word groups sharing an initial sound
Knows the sounds associated with most letters
Identifies, blends, & segments syllables in spoken words
Develops auditory discrimination skills
Recognizes similar and different sounds
Identifies rhyming words

attributes.name: Demonstrates knowledge of print & alphabet
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A younger child may make up words based on groupings of letter. An older child may begin to put groupings of letters together to write words and sentences.

progressionPoints.description: Demonstrates a beginning understanding that print carries meaning
Distinguishes print from pictures
Understands that letters are symbols
Understands written words are made up of a group of individual letters
Recognizes & names some letters of the alphabet, including letters in own name
Names most letters (identifying more uppercase, than lower case letters)
Demonstrates an understanding of basic conventions of print
Understands & uses clusters of letters to represent words.
Identifies one's own printed name and the names of others, with minimal adult support
Identifies some basic sight words
Demonstrates awareness that letters hold individual speech sounds
Begins to sound-out short words

attributes.name: Understands & interacts with books and text
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may hold a book and pretend to read and/or turn the pages. An older child may begin to read simple words and sentences.

progressionPoints.description: Shows interest in books, pictures, songs, & rhymes
Actively participates in book reading & storytelling; holding book & turning pages
Points to familiar pictures in books.
Asks & answers questions about main characters & events in familiar stories
Demonstrates an understanding of the meaning of stories and information in books
Begins to point to simple words while reading simple, memorized texts
Identifies book parts & features
Tells stories using a sequence of three connected events
Demonstrates an understanding of the differences between fantasy & reality
Talks about facts and the main idea of a text
Tells a story to an adult while the adult writes it down
Draws pictures to show what happens in the story

attributes.name: Uses writing for a variety of purposes
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A younger child may begin to use crayons to make scribbles on paper. An older child may make a sign to preserve a block structure they have made.

progressionPoints.description: Attends to and shows interest while adults (or others) write
Makes marks on paper to explore crayons, paint, and other materials
Makes scribbles or simple shapes to represent objects or actions
Shows interest in using writing materials, imitating adults' use
Makes letter-like marks on paper
Progressively uses drawing & letter-like forms to intentionally convey meaning
Writes or draws for a variety of purposes and demonstrates evidence of many aspects of print conventions
Writes letters in first and last name using upper case letter and lower case letters
Writes letters and words to label or to tell a story about one's own picture
Writes using invented spelling, demonstrating some knowledge of association between letter and sound
Begins to use technology to create simple text and drawings

attributes.name: Observes, explores, & describes their environment to gain understanding of people, places, & things
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may put a toy in their mouth to explore its properties. An older child may use a microscope to get a closer look at a leaf they found outside.

progressionPoints.description: Experiments with everyday objects & materials to answer what, why, or how questions
Uses the five senses to observe objects, materials, & events
Represents observable phenomena through drawing
Begins to use scientific vocabulary
Asks questions that can be answered through investigation
Plans & implements investigations & experiments
Uses scientific practice words or signs such as observe, predict, experiment, & measure
Identifies the five senses & uses them to make observations
Uses tools & technology to extend observations.
Represents observable phenomena with pictures, diagrams, & 3D models
Uses various sources of information in research, discussion, and inquiry
Explains how various peoples and cultures in the United States celebrate their histories (like with holidays)
Asks questions about the natural world
Independently seeks information. Asks why, what, how, what if questions when exploring materials
Develops sequence of questions based on investigations: Do worms sleep?  Where do they go when it snows?

attributes.name: Compares & categorizes objects, materials, events
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A younger child may put all of the blue blocks in a pile and all of the red blocks in a pile. An older child may use a tape measure to evaluate how many inches tall they are in comparison to the other children.

progressionPoints.description: Collects or gathers like objects (e.g. leaves, sticks, blocks)
Matches objects by similar characteristics
Sorts objects into groups based on simple attributes such as color, shape, & size
Uses simple measurement tools to quantify similarities & differences
Orders objects by measurable attributes
Identifies characteristics of people & things.
Uses standard & non-standard measurement to observe & compare (objects, materials, and events)
Sorts objects into groups based on complex attributes such as weight, texture, or sound
Uses comparative language
Discovers how people and events from the past relate to the present
Explains how maps and globes are similar and different. Make maps, drawings, or models to show how familiar places (like the school)
Solves problems using the skills and tools of engineers and scientists
Classifies objects with two or more characteristics (red, square blocks)
Uses one-to-one correspondence as a strategy
Arranges objects in order by height, size, weight, most, least etc.
Articulates comparisons among objects

attributes.name: Demonstrates an understanding of cause-and-effect
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may repeatedly drop a toy to see what happens. An older child may make a prediction about what will happen on the next page of a story.

progressionPoints.description: Repeats an action to make things happen or to get an adult to repeat an action
Engages in purposeful actions to cause things to happen
Makes simple predictions about what will happen next (in a story or in daily routines and play)
Draws conclusions, constructs explanations, & verbalizes cause & effect relationships
Explores how things change depending on a variable (e.g. temperature)
Compares what happens when objects are pushed or pulled in different ways

attributes.name: Uses reasoning & problem-solving skills
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may crawl over to the other side of the room to retrieve a toy they want to play with. An older child may look to find an answer to a question in a book in the library.

progressionPoints.description: Uses body movements & actions to solve simple problems and/or explore environment
Uses a variety of simple strategies to try to solve problems
Engages in simple investigations & experiments
Makes simple scientific predictions
Solves problems based on past experiences or by devising a plan
Can articulate reasoning for actions and/or solutions.
Analyzes & interprets data
Gathers information about a question using observation, books, & technology
Shows interest in common instruments for measuring (e.g. height, weight, length, temperature)
Arranges objects from shortest to longest, shortest to tallest, lightest to heaviest
Compares three or more things using some comparison words appropriately (e.g. small, smallest). Estimates and measure using non-standard measurement tools.
Collects data and makes records using lists or graphs
Develops hypotheses and conclusions, makes predictions

attributes.name: Demonstrates an understanding of number names, order, & quantity
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may use the sign for "more" when wanting more food at lunch. An older child may count to 20 or more in sequence without missing any numbers.

progressionPoints.description: Attends to quantity in play with objects, such as reaching or looking for more than one object
Uses simple signs to refer to quantity such as "more"
Uses basic words to refer to quantity such as "more" and "all gone"
Begins to use basic number words
Uses fingers to show how old they are
Identifies "more" or "less" with a small number of items without needing to count them
Says or signs number words in sequence (up to 10)
Develops an understanding of whole numbers
Shows an understanding of 1:1 correspondence
Says or signs number words in sequence (up to 20)
Recognizes small quantities of up to five objects and says or signs the number
Understands that the last number said represents the number of objects in a set
Utilizes & uses numbers related to order & position (up to 10th)
Recognizes, names, and writes numerals 0-20
Counts to 100 by ones or tens, starting from any number
Explains that numbers in the "teens" (11- 19) are made of a ten and some ones
Creates groups of 10 with manipulatives

attributes.name: Demonstrates an understanding of shapes, spatial sense, & patterns
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may watch an adult as they move from one side of the room to the other. An older child may be able to recite the names of advanced shapes like an octagon, and tell you how many sides it has.

progressionPoints.description: Explores or examines objects & watches when they move
Shows awareness when an object is not in its usual place
Explores & discovers how things move through space and/or fit together
Demonstrates awareness of size
Explores & completes simple puzzles
Recognizes simple patterns
Recognizes & names simple shapes
Understands simple spatial vocabulary
Fills in missing elements of patterns
Creates, identifies, extends, & duplicates simple patterns with objects, numbers, sounds, & movement
Names & describes a greater number of shapes, and does so using length, number of sides, & angles
Analyzes, compares & sorts 2D and 3D shapes & objects.
Understands & uses directional vocabulary
Names, describes, analyzes, and compares shapes like squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres
Identifies shared two-dimensional shapes as well as diamonds, ovals, etc.
Identifies existing visual and oral patterns (e.g. AB, ABC, AAB, ABB)
Copies and extends existing visual and oral patterns
Creates new visual and oral patterns

attributes.name: Demonstrates an understanding of simple operations
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS OR TODDLERS. A younger child may be able to state how many children may play in an interest area based on the number of children they observe there in that moment. An older child may be able to use tally marks to keep track of the score in a simple game.

progressionPoints.description: Begins to show understanding of math terms such as more than, less than, difference, all together, or take away
Manipulates objects to achieve a goal (i.e. giving one more napkin so everyone has one, or removing a chair to have the correct number)
Begins to add & subtract small collections of objects, with support
Represents addition & subtraction in different way (fingers, objects, drawings)
Solves simple addition & subtraction word problems
Finds the number that makes 10 for any number 1-9, with minimal adult support. For example, 6 needs 4 to make 10.
Breaks numbers into smaller numbers, with minimal adult support, for example, 5 is made of 2 and 3 or 4 and 1.
Uses math to make arguments about why something is true or false
Adds and subtracts with numbers up to five, with minimal adult support

attributes.name: Uses imitation & symbolic representation in play
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may be able to play peek-a-boo with an adult; imitating the hand motions. An older child may take on the role of cashier during a game of supermarket in the dramatic play area.

progressionPoints.description: Engages in reciprocal imitation games
Imitates the earlier actions of others
Uses toy objects in ways that are similar to the real objects they represent
Imitates complex or multi-step actions of others
Acts out routines or social roles
Uses objects as symbols to represent other objects
Improvises with props during dramatic play
Uses symbols to represent thinking in play
Participates cooperatively in complex pretend play, with predetermined roles & plans
Visualizes environments and arranges the physical playing space to communicate mood, time, and locale

attributes.name: Maintains focus & sustains attention
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may follow the movement and sound of a wind chime. An older child may work on a building structure over the span of several days until it is completed.

progressionPoints.description: Attends to auditory and visual stimuli
Maintains focus & attention on a simple task or activity for short periods of time with adult support
Maintains focus & attention on a simple task or activity for short periods of time independently
Maintains focus & attention on more complex tasks or activities over extended periods of times (days or weeks)
Span of attention increases; works at task for longer periods of time
Is able to pay attention and is not distracted by sounds not noticed by others
Attends to a group story or activity for 15 to 20 minutes

attributes.name: Ability to remember information to use in later tasks
attributes.categoryInformation: A younger child may smile or squeal when their parent arrives to pick them up for the day. An older child may be able to play a memory matching game with success.

progressionPoints.description: Recognizes familiar people, places, and things
Recalls singular details to a story, activity, or event
Holds small amounts of information in mind to follow and complete two-step directions
Recounts details to a story or experience in order
Holds increasing amounts of information in mind to follow & complete multi-step directions
Recalls the main idea and some details of the story/discussion, with minimal adult support

attributes.name: Demonstrates flexibility in thoughts, actions, & behavior
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A younger child may be able to put materials away in preparation to go outside. An older child may be able to have a conversation with another child about what to do when they both want to use the same materials.

progressionPoints.description: Demonstrates the ability to transition from one task or activity to another with consistent adult support
Regularly transitions from one task or activity to another with intermittent adult support
Utilizes more than one strategy to complete work and/or solve a simple problem
Successfully transitions from one task or activity to another independently
Utilizes multiple strategies to complete work and/or solve increasingly complex problems without adult support
Understands concepts, such as simple time markers (today, tomorrow, yesterday)
Talks self through steps required in simple problem solving situations
Is able to cope with an unexpected change, most of the time

attributes.name: Demonstrates persistence in actions & behaviors
attributes.categoryInformation: A child may attend to a simple puzzle until they are able to get every single piece to fit correctly.

progressionPoints.description: Repeats simple actions to achieve a goal
Stays engaged in an activity to successfully complete a simple task
Engages in an activity to successfully complete more complex tasks for increasingly longer amounts of time
Engages in activities to successfully complete tasks from beginning to end, despite potential challenges or obstacles
Is highly involved and persistent in problem solving; tries alternative methods when needed. Seek answers through reflection; asks for help when needed.

attributes.name: Demonstrates use of creativity & imagination in learning & play
attributes.categoryInformation: NOT OBSERVED IN INFANTS. A younger child may pretend a block is a telephone by holding it up to their ear and talking. An older child may take on character roles during dramatic play (family members, store clerk, story characters, etc.

progressionPoints.description: Uses objects and materials in novel ways during play
Experiments with more than one material or approach when engaged in an activity or solitary/independent play
Uses pretend or imaginary objects in social play
Takes on the role of another ("I'm the mommy")
Uses objects and materials in increasingly innovative ways
Engages in inventive social play
Engages in elaborate and extended role-play
Uses props in play to create complex scenarios
Designs and constructs with blocks and other three-dimensional materials
Draws, paints, and uses multi-media to create representations with many details
